review_title: Decent Job but Disorganized and Poorly Managed College
pros: Great students, friendly staff and co-workers, laid back work environment, schedule flexibility, some good perks and benefits from the State of Georgia. Lots of autonomy and trust to teach your class without much follow up (which at times wasn't always a good thing, as I wanted more feedback).
cons: Lack of communication, disorganized, last minute scheduling and cancellations, and lack of support/resources for teaching. The facilities are outdated and many of the classrooms are run down and have problems (electrical issues, computer issues, leaking ceilings, etc). The hiring/interview process was extremely disorganized. It was drawn out over a long period of time, and then suddenly everything was needed within 24 hours and it was very stressful. Pay is not great for the work -- adjuncts are paid a set sum per course, but obviously there is a lot more work that goes into the teaching than just the hours spent in the classroom. The hours put in on a weekly basis are not worth it when you see your paycheck, and that eats away at your motivation and morale over time.

pros: Successful teachers at ATC learn learn how to manage time, grade efficiently, collaborate with others, and become flexible.  If you are a grad student (with enough experience to qualify for a job here), teaching here will help you hone the soft skills that one needs outside of academic credentials to succeed in academia. Additionally, there are a few great people in leadership positions who are making efforts - and headway - in positive change.
cons: The teaching load is unrealistically enormous, the pay for adjunct instructors is insulting, and there seems to be little if any support for general education instructors who seek professional development opportunities within their fields.

pros: There is job stability at the college.
cons: The president does not care about the students nor the faculty.  She always says she does but you cannot believe anything that she says.  Faculty and staff have not received raises in over eight years.  Georgia is an open records state and we are able to see that she continues to give herself and her senior management sorority sisters raises.

review_title: I enjoyed teaching at Atlanta Technical College.
pros: I enjoyed the work hours. There is a lot of flexibility working on the college level. I love the fact that the students who are there-want to be there for the most part. Therefore, instructors don't have to do discipline the students like in public schools.
cons: The GED students were not as mature as the regular-ed students, so in teaching GED students, instructors have to be really firm and set the guidelines for the classroom.

pros: There are friendly, helpful people on the faculty. My students were, on the whole, dedicated to improving their circumstances, which makes for an exciting teaching environment.
cons: Pay is low for adjunct instructors. This is not the administration's fault, but it is why I left.

pros: Flexible, doing something much needed. Can be very rewarding.  Teaching is an admirable profession but not nearly as rewarded. I love it
cons: Pay. Pay is hourly but the number of hours is minimal so you need a second job. It's not meant to be s primary source as it is a part time position.
